We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms reported by the patient suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The specific test for SLE diagnosis is the presence of antibody to double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), making option (B) the correct answer. Antibodies to microsomal cellular organelles (option A) are found in hepatitis and other liver diseases. Antibodies to phospholipids of cell membranes (option C) are found in antiphospholipid syndrome, which presents with recurrent thrombosis and an increased risk of miscarriage. Antibodies to ribonucleoprotein (option D) are found in mixed connective tissue disease, which presents with a combination of autoimmune features from SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis.
